newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel bonds close higher triggering lower yields.
newsitem.headline: Israel bonds close higher triggering lower yields.

text.p: Israeli bonds closed up on Thursday in active demand for most kinds of bonds causing yields to continue to fall, traders said.
* Bank of Israel short-term Makam bills: +0.06 to 104.99

"Today we saw a continuation of the trend of lower yields," said Ilan Doron of Solid Capital Markets. "Yields of CPI-linked bonds are going in the direction of four percent and lower, and yields of unlinked bonds are at 13.8 percent. Makam's are at 13.7 percent."

"Demand for unlinked bonds was up because of estimates that the April consumer price index will be lower than expected. We forecast that April's CPI will be a surprise and lower than the expected 1.1-1.2 percent mainly because of lower house prices," he said.
"Demand for CPI-linked bonds was up as well because there is lack of supply in the market. The government is issuing less CPI-linked bonds," Doron said.
April's CPI, which will be published on May 15, is generally high due to the Passover holiday. Forecasts are that it will be around the 1.0-1.2 percent.
"Prices of dollar-linked bonds were lower today and yields on some bonds were above seven percent. Yesterday yields were at around 6.8 percent," said a trader at IBI Investment House.
"Traders were afraid that the dollar would weaken against the shekel after having weakened in the world markets, but the exchange rate was unchanged today," the trader said.
The representative rate for the dollar was fixed at 3.4030 shekels against 3.4040 on Wednesday.
On Sunday and Monday there will be no trading on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange because of the Israeli Memorial and Independence Days.
Note: Makams are zero-coupon unlinked certificates with durations of three months to one year. The Bank of Israel issues Makams to absorb liquidity.
